citations.narrative:
During the inspection there were several examples of non-human primates having access to inappropriate materials.
- There was a detached metal wire inside “Ahimsa Central” that two brown capuchins could access.
- There was a shredded plastic grocery bag inside “Swing Shift” which houses two brown capuchins.
- There was a plastic grape bag inside “Thunderdome” which houses three spider monkeys.
Access to foreign items or broken enclosure materials can result in illness or injury. Housing facilities must be kept in
good repair and protect the animals from injury. The facility removed all inappropriate items at the time of inspection.

There is a build-up of fecal matter and food inside the heat cave for “Ahimsa Central” which houses two brown capuchins.
There is also a build up of fecal matter, dirt, and hair on the ramps and tunnel access for two enclosures inside “Julie’s
Wellness Jungle”.
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where nonhuman primates can come in contact can result in an
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations,
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance
with 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards.
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
Additional Inspectors:
David Mersereau, VETERINARY MEDICAL OFFICER n

narrative:
3.75(a)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
During the inspection there were several examples of non-human primates having access to inappropriate materials. 
- There was a detached metal wire inside “Ahimsa Central” that two brown capuchins could access.  
- There was a shredded plastic grocery bag inside “Swing Shift” which houses two brown capuchins. 
- There was a plastic grape bag inside “Thunderdome” which houses three spider monkeys.  
 
Access to foreign items or broken enclosure materials can result in illness or injury. Housing facilities must be kept in 
good repair and protect the animals from injury. The facility removed all inappropriate items at the time of inspection. 
3.75(c)(3)  Repeat
   
Housing facilities, general. 
There is a build-up of fecal matter and food inside the heat cave for “Ahimsa Central” which houses two brown capuchins. 
There is also a build up of fecal matter, dirt, and hair on the ramps and tunnel access for two enclosures inside “Julie’s 
Wellness Jungle”.  
 
Not maintaining appropriate levels of cleanliness in areas where nonhuman primates can come in contact can result in an 
excessive build-up of materials, which can increase the disease risk for the animals contained within. Per the regulations, 
hard surfaces with which nonhuman primates come in contact must be spot cleaned daily and sanitized in accordance 
with 3.84 of this subpart to prevent accumulation of excreta or disease hazards. 
 
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
